h3. Problem Definition
Currently, the prediction in the [Version report|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRASOFTWARECLOUD/Version+Report] is based on average velocity. Customer would want to be able to tweak these options

h3. Suggested Solution
Customer's comment:
{quote}
I'd like a way to either specify/override the velocity used in the prediction manually or for example, by having options for the velocity used for the release date prediction, e.g. with these options:
* average over version (current)
* average over last x weeks (where x is editable)
* average over last y sprints(where y is editable)
* manually tweakable number
{quote}

 
h3. Workaround 
-

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64164].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently in Cloud it's not possible to export more than 1k issues at the same time.
Due to this limitation, customers are exporting the issues in batches. However, doing so with "All fields" selected, will not always display the same columns, specially if one of the batches have an empty custom field for all exported issues, in which case the custom field won't appear.
The same happens for the option "With current columns".

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide static headers for the CSV Export. This way customers can always expected the CSV document to be the same.
fields.summary: CSV Export should always export with the same header order and fields

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Caches in JIRA Data Center are self invalidating
h3. Environment
 * JIRA datacenter - *Only Data Center customers are affected by this issue*

*Symptoms*
 # JIRA is unstable with high CPU usage and high GC, requests are dropped.
 # On DB level one can observe high traffic to *projectroleactor* table.
{code:borderStyle=solid}
SELECT ID, PID, PROJECTROLEID, ROLETYPE, ROLETYPEPARAMETER FROM projectroleactor WHERE PROJECTROLEID=:1
{code}
 # Following error messages in logs maybe present 
 ** 
{code:java}
Looking up rmiUrl NODE_ADDRESS/com.atlassian.jira.security.roles.CachingProjectRoleAndActorStore.projectRoleActors threw a connection exception.
{code}

 * 
 ** 
{code:java}
[c.a.jira.cluster.ReplicatorExecutorServiceFactory] Cache replication thread pool is too small. Try increasing number of threads by setting system property com.atlassian.cache.parallelReplicationThreadCount.
{code}

 * 
 ** Stack traces with dbcpool exhausted symptoms. 

*Steps to reproduce (to be verified)*
 # Setup JIRA Data Center cluster with minimum two nodes, the more the better
 # Create thousands of projects 
 # Start multiple treads that are executing JIRA agile dashboard
 ** Those calls must be calling all the nodes
 # Create project
 # JIRA should start unstable behaviour. 

 

*Root cause*
 # JIRA 6.4 used {{com.atlassian.cache.CacheFactory#getCache(java.lang.String, com.atlassian.cache.CacheLoader<K,V>, com.atlassian.cache.CacheSettings)}} with cache loaders.
 ** Caches constructed this way are LoadingCache which is BlockingCache this means that cacheLoader will load value exactly once for each key.
 ** The value will be reloaded only when invalidated.
 # JIRA 7.2 caches were migrated to use cache without CacheLoader and started executing method.
 {{com.atlassian.vcache.LocalCacheOperations#get(K, java.util.function.Supplier<? extends V>)}}
 ** Caches constructed this way are *not blocking* and the get with supplier operation is not blocking.
 ** This means that multiple treads will try to load the same value from the loader.
 ** If two treads load the values for the same key then one of them will execute put on ehcache in the situation when value already exists in the cache. In other words one of the threads overrides value that was stored by the other thread.
 ** In this situation ehcache recognises this as value update and triggers invalidation on all the other nodes.
 ** As a result of the invalidation all other nodes are very likely to trigger the same invalidation behaviour making the problem even worse. This effectively remove caching for those values and multiplies invalidation traffic across nodes.

This issue affects 21 caches in total the most significant being {{CachingProjectRoleAndActorStore}}

List of caches
{noformat}
com.atlassian.jira.issue.managers.CachingCustomFieldManager
com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.screen.CachingFieldScreenStore
com.atlassian.jira.project.util.CachingProjectKeyStore
com.atlassian.jira.project.CachingProjectManager
com.atlassian.jira.security.roles.CachingProjectRoleAndActorStore
com.atlassian.jira.security.auth.trustedapps.CachingTrustedApplicationStore
com.atlassian.jira.workflow.CachingWorkflowDescriptorStore
com.atlassian.jira.config.DefaultConstantsManager
com.atlassian.jira.util.DefaultDurationFormatterProvider
com.atlassian.jira.event.type.DefaultEventTypeManager
com.atlassian.jira.config.feature.DefaultFeatureManager
com.atlassian.jira.issue.link.DefaultIssueLinkTypeManager
com.atlassian.jira.config.DefaultReindexMessageManager
com.atlassian.jira.service.DefaultServiceManager
com.atlassian.jira.workflow.DefaultWorkflowSchemeManager
com.atlassian.jira.workflow.EagerWorkflowSchemeManager
com.atlassian.jira.issue.context.persistence.FieldConfigContextPersisterWorker
com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.config.persistence.FieldConfigPersisterImpl
com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.config.persistence.FieldConfigSchemePersisterImpl
com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.managers.FieldIndexerManagerImpl
com.atlassian.jira.issue.security.IssueSecurityLevelManagerImpl

{noformat}
fields.summary: Caches in JIRA Data Center are self invalidating

Even when the user has only one JIRA window open, after editing the issue, randomly receives a popup message advertising that himself else was editing the issue and needs to refresh the page to see the latest data.
 !Screen Shot 2017-02-20 at 10.55.27 AM.png|thumbnail!

Steps to reproduce:
# Open a JIRA Cloud window
# Create any Issue.
# Click on *edit* button
# change something: could be the description and leave in edit mode for 30 seconds or more, for example.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64160].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, JIRA stores the worklog, in the {{worklog}} table under the original name of the user. 
Example, if John's username was changed from john01 to john02. When he logs work, JIRA would log the work as john02. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Once the username has changed, then all existing worklogs have to be updated to the new name and all future worklogs must be done in the new username. 

h3. Why this is important
This could cause confusion to anyone analyzing the data directly from the DB and give them incorrect results.
fields.summary: As an Admin, I would like JIRA's worklog table to store worklog for a user with respect to the latest username of the user
Have full project sidebar for any board

fields.description:
As stated in the title, the linked status of every step in draft workflow cannot be edited. If you make a copy of an 'Active' state workflow, you will be able to edit the linked status. I believe that both creating a copy of a workflow and making a draft workflow should have the same ability in editing the linked status of a step.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Create a workflow and activate it by associating with a workflow scheme and then to a project.
 # Create draft for the 'Active' state workflow
 # Click on the +Steps+ under the newly created draft workflow
 # Click on any Step Name
 # Then, click on +Edit+ step

See the image attachments for clarification.
h3. Expected behaviour

The Linked Status should be editable in Draft Mode.
h3. Actual behaviour

The Linked Status to the Step Name is *uneditable* (blurred out). In addition to that, underneath the Linked Status option, you will be seeing the following description:
{noformat}
Cannot change the linked status of an existing workflow step. 
{noformat}
h3. Workaround
 # Go to *JIRA administration > issues > workflow*
 # *Make a copy* of the workflow that you need to edit
 # Once you have made a copy now the workflow will be present in be present in an inactive mode.
 # Under *operation* click edit and perform the necessary changes that you need to make.
 # Once you have make the changes associate the updated workflow to the respective project via project administration.
fields.summary: Linked Status is not editable in Draft Workflow when it is supposed to be editable

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 17 July 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

ALM Works has released a new version of Structure 4.1. 
Since the version "S" access key has removed from the Structure menu item.

JIRA access keys have not been modified to address this problem.

--
Cheers,
Ignat Alexeyenko
JIRA Bugmaster
{panel}


h3. Summary
JIRA's Form Submit Keyboard shortcut in Firefox doesn't work as expected when Structure plugin is installed. Shortcut to the JIRA Menu dropdown such as Dashboards/Projects/Issues uses "Alt + Shift + <first letter>" which translates to "Alt + Shift + D/P/I". Structure is a third-party plugin that uses the same concept but this collides with existing "Form Submit" keyboard shortcut in Firefox on Windows.

h3. Environment
 * JIRA 6.x, 7.2.7
 * Strucuter installed (version earlier than 4.1)
 * Firefox browser
 * Windows OS

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to an issue
 # Try to add a comment
 # Use "Alt + Shift + S" to submit comment

h3. Expected Results

The comment will be added correctly with the shortcut
h3. Actual Results

The shortcut highlights the Structure menu on top
h3. Notes

The same "Form Submit" shortcut works correctly on Chrome's Mac OS, where the same method is being used trying to highlight the Top Menu and Submitting a form (Ctrl + Alt/Option + S). It will submit the comment when the Comment Box is triggered, and when not, highlight the "Structure" menu.

h3. Additional tests 7.2 with Structure plugin
(/) - Working as expected
(x) - Not working at all
(-) - Open Structure menu
RTE - Rich Text Editor

h5. Windows 7 + Firefox
|| Conditions || Add comment || Update description || Edit screen ||
|RTE off, no Structure | (x) Open FF menu | (/) | (/) |
|RTE off, with Structure | (-) | (/) | (-) |

h5. Mac OS + Firefox
|| Conditions || Add comment || Update description|| Edit screen ||
|RTE off, no Structure | (x) | (x) | (x) |
|RTE off, with Structure | (x) | (x) | (x) |

h3. Workaround
# Use Ctrl+Enter shortcut
# Use Chrome browser on Windows OS
# Update to Structure 4.1
fields.summary: Form Submit Keyboard Shortcut collide with Top menu Shortcut in Firefox

h3. Summary
Attempting to comment with the text tab then canceling will disable the visual tab until the page is refreshed

h3. Environment
* IE 11.0.96

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enter issue in Internet Explorer (not an error in Chrome)
# Click Comment button in bottom of issue (or use shortcut key "m")
# Select Text tab
# Click Cancel
# Click Comment button in bottom of issue (or use shortcut key "m")
# Select Visual tab

h3. Expected Results
You should be able to select the visual tab with the cursor and edit the comment.

h3. Actual Results
Cursor cannot focus the visual tab and you cannot add or edit a comment in the visual tab.
fields.summary: Cannot get cursor in Visual tab in comment after cancelling comment on IE

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Email notifications are sent even if *Issue Comment Deleted* notifications are disabled in the notification scheme.

Notifications for this event appear to be tied to *Issue Updated*.

h4. Environment
* Default Notification Scheme from standard installation.

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Edit notification scheme
# Delete all notifications from Issue Comment Deleted event
# Create a new issue
# Add a comment to the issue
# Delete the comment

h4. Expected Results
No notification should be sent to any users as:
* There are not notifications associated to the event
* The event is shown as "Inactive" in Administration -> System -> Advanced -> Events

h4. Actual Results
Email notifications are sent for the deleted comment to all users configured to receive "Issue Updated" notifications.

h4. Notes
* This also applies to comment deletion via REST API
* The root cause seems to be deleting a comment will fire an Issue Updated event rather than Issue Comment Deleted
fields.summary: Issue comment deleted notifications are sent even if disabled in notification scheme

fields.description:
Issue links continually gain extra hyphens "-" when using Rich Text Editor.
 * Ensure that Rich Text Editor is enabled
 * Video of problems attached

h5. Problem 1 - copy/paste issue link
 # Edit Description box and add an closed issue that will automatically render into a link, example:
{code:java}
JRA-1
{code}

 # Save - this will render into a link with a strikethrough, as expected. (ie. --JRA-1--)
 # Copy the rendered text

 ** Do not choose to "copy link", just simply "copy"
 # Edit the description again
 # Switch to Visual mode and paste the copied text
 # Observe that the --JRA-1-- text has been auto-formated as a link
 # Switch to Text mode
 # The text now shows as:
{code:java}
-JRA-1-

-JRA-1-
{code}

 # Save
 # Repeat: Edit description, switch to Visual mode, and paste the same link
 # Switch to text and now we see:
{code:java}
--JRA-1--

--JRA-1--

-JRA-1-
{code}

 # Upon saving you will see ----JRA-1---- (note the extra -)
 # Repeating the same steps will continue to add more -

h5. Problem 2 - editing in visual mode
 # Maintain what we see from problem 1 in text mode:
{code:java}
--JRA-1--

--JRA-1--

-JRA-1-
{code}

 # Switch to Visual mode and save
 # Edit again, which will automatically be in Visual mode
 # Add some random text without modifying the existing links
 # Switch to Text mode
 # Observe that it now looks like this:
{code:java}
---JRA-1---

---JRA-1---

--JRA-1--

asdf
{code}

 # Save
 # Now the render has double extra hypens around the struck-through link, like so: -----JRA-1-----
fields.summary: Rich Text Editor Switch between Visual and Text mode has problems with Issue Links

fields.description:
Currently within the doc [Migrating JIRA applications to another server - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/migrating-jira-applications-to-another-server-861253107.html] has the steps of:
{quote}
3.6 Import your old data into your new JIRA applications

After you have started your new JIRA installation you should be logged in to your JIRA application, and ready to import the data from your old instance into the new instance. You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions ( above).

To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:

# Log in as a user with the 'JIRA System Administrators' global permission.
# Select Administration > System > Import & Export > Restore System (tab) to open the 'Restore JIRA data from Backup' page.
# In the File name field, specify the XML backup file you created previously during the export process (above). That zipped file should contain two xml files: activeobjects.xml and entities.xml. Both of these files must be included in the zipped file for the import process to work.
# Restore the attachments directory that you backed up previously, into the attachments directory of your new JIRA. (See Restoring data.)
    (info) Avoid passing through a proxy when performing an XML restore, especially if your JIRA instance is very large. Using a proxy may cause timeout errors. 
{quote}

But this is not actually what happens here.  If you follow all these step up to this point, when you start JIRA, you won't actually be logged into JIRA at all (how could you, the database is totally empty at this point).  When you start JIRA with an empty data as was the steps of this doc, you start JIRA in the initial setup wizard.  From here you can actually click the link for 'import existing data' and then simply select the XML backup here to restore.

That part is a minor difference but I would like to clarify that first.   In order to follow the steps in the current guide, you would need to create a new admin account and finish the initial setup wizard of JIRA before you can gain access to the System -> Restore data option.  Which is just misleading.

Also there is a bigger problem with following these steps if you are also upgrading JIRA at this time.  If you follow these current steps, and JIRA is upgraded to a new version where the naming convention of attachments has changed (I know it has happened between 6.4 and 7.0, and again in 7.2), then following these steps will result in your previous attachments in JIRA being inaccessible to you in the new instance because the database references for these files in the {{fileattachments}} table get updated with the new naming convention when the XML import happens, but the actual flat files themselves are not in place in order for JIRA to rename them yet.  Leaving the customer with broken attachments that are actually a pain to fix and additional support cases waiting to happen.


Instead I would recommend these steps:


{panel:borderStyle=dashed| borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

3.6 Import your old data into your new JIRA applications

After you have started your new JIRA installation you will notice that JIRA will launch its initial setup wizard.   This happens anytime JIRA starts with an empty database.  From here you can import your backup file in order to populate your XML backup data into your new empty database. You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions ( above).

To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:

# Restore the attachments directory that you backed up previously, into the attachments directory of your new JIRA. (See Restoring data.)
# Start JIRA
# In the setup wizard select the option for 'Import existing data'
# In the File name field, specify the XML backup file you created previously during the export process (above). That zipped file should contain two xml files: activeobjects.xml and entities.xml. Both of these files must be included in the zipped file for the import process to work.
    (info) Avoid passing through a proxy when performing an XML restore, especially if your JIRA instance is very large. Using a proxy may cause timeout errors.  
{panel}

Steps 5 and 6 on that doc should be unchanged.
fields.summary: Migrating JIRA server documentation update for data restore

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64143].
{panel}
h3. *Summary*

The JQL searches "watcher !=" and "watcher not in" are not working properly, they will return only issues where there is a watcher and it's not the user.
h3. *Steps to Reproduce*
 # Create a new project (ex: TEST)
 # Create a new issue (ex: TEST-1)
 # Create two users, admin1 and admin2
 # Perform the JQL search: project = TEST and watcher != admin1, it will not return any issue.
 # Add admin2 as watcher in TEST-1.
 # Perform the JQL search: project = TEST and watcher != admin1, it will return the issue TEST-1.

h3. *Expected Results*

The JQL "watcher != user" should return all issues where the user is not a watcher.
h3. *Actual Results*

The JQL "watcher != user" only returns issues where the user is not a watcher and there is at least one watcher. Issues
h3. *Details*

When we define a user as a watcher, we actually create a relationship, that is an entry in the {{userassociation}} table of the type WatchIssue. So when we tell Jira {{watcher != currentUser()}} what it does is search relationships of watchers that don't match the current user.
fields.summary: The JQL "watcher != user" and "watcher not in" are not working.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64142].
  {panel}

We received a request to add some steps that may facilitate the SSL implementation steps.
Customer was facing some issues to integrate JIRA with HIpChat over SSL.
Here is the steps taken:
{quote}
IMPORTANT: private key and keystore password need to be the SAME. If not then you need to specifiy the password for the private key *6)
1) Create CSR and private key on your linux box:
openssl req -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout private.key -out request.csr -subj "/C=na/ST=None/L=None/O=None/CN=None"
2) Create certificate with the generated CSR for your domain. (in StartSSL go to "Certificates Wizard", paste the generated CSR for your domain and submit. Download and extract the certificate and CA Chain.)
3) Create PFX file from certificate (step 2), private key (step 1) and Certificate Chain (step 2 - root bundle or intermediate cert depending on CA):
openssl pkcs12 -export -out <PFX-filename>.pfx -inkey private.key -in <your-certificate>.crt -certfile <CA-chain-file>.crt
(you can use the same password for the PFX file as for the private key to make things easier - we won't need the PFX file later and can destroy it)
The output should read like this:
>Enter pass phrase for private.key:
>Enter Export Password:
>Verifying - Enter Export Password:
4) Convert the PFX into a Java keystore. In your JRE bin directory on your linux box execute:
./keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore <PFX-filename>.pfx -destkeystore <new-keystore-file>.keystore -srcstoretype PKCS12 -deststoretype JKS
IMPORTANT: Use the SAME PASSWORD for the keystore as for the private key from step 1)! otherwise see *6)
The output should read like this:
>Enter destination keystore password:
>Re-enter new password:
>Enter source keystore password:
>Entry for alias 1 successfully imported.
>Import command completed:  1 entries successfully imported, 0 entries failed or cancelled
5)Edit your server.xml, uncomment the <Connector port="8443> and point the keystore entry to your <new-keystore>.keystore and supply the keystore password from step 1. (keystoreFile="<new-keystore>.keystore" keystorePass="<password from step 1>")
*6) If you want to set different passwords for the private key and the keystore then you have to:
./keytool -keypasswd -keystore /path/to/keyestore.file -alias <alias-in-keystore>
If you're not sure about the alias: ./keytool -list -keystore <name-of-keystore>
*7) Alternative to creating a PFX file including the CA chain file:
./keytool -importcert -alias startssl-CA-chain -keystore <path-to-atlassian-directory>/jre/lib/security/cacerts -file <CA Chain Cert in PEM format>.crt
{quote}
fields.summary: SSL documentation improve request

fields.description:
h3. Summary
According to the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRASOFTWARESERVER072/Allowing+OAuth+access], every token expires after 7 days. However older tokens are still valid on JIRA Software 7.2.7 server. Looking at the screen, from the user profile we don't seem that we indicate any expiration data and old tokens are still valid.
We need to clarify if/when does OAuth token expire. Then the documentation needs to be adjusted accordingly. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/ViewProfile.jspa
# Then to Tools > _View OAuth Access Tokens_ 
#* Or directly to https://jira.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/oauth/users/access-tokens 

h3. Expected Results
According to the documentation every token expires after 7 days.

h3. Actual Results
From the user profile we don't seem that we indicate any expiration data and old tokens are still valid.
The documentation needs to be adjusted.
 !Screen Shot 2017-02-17 at 15.23.17.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Documentation request: OAuth access doesn't expire

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64137].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When JIRA Gadgets queries its text resources via browser, JIRA's back-end attempts to do an internal call to itself using the _BaseURL_. In case of complex network setup this could be a problem as proxy might not allow connection from JIRA back to JIRA. 

h3. Suggested Solution
JIRA server shouldn't connect to itself though network using the _BaseURL_.

h3. Workaround 
Possible workaround is described at [How to fix gadget titles showing as __MSG_gadget|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/how-to-fix-gadget-titles-showing-as-__msg_gadget-813697086.html]
fields.summary: As an JIRA Administrator I want JIRA to do call to itself by internal call instead of remote network call

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JIRA's Activity Stream does not display any information from Bitbucket Server 

h3. Environment
# Atlassian Bitbucket v4.11.1
# Atlassian Bitbucket v4.12.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup application link between JIRA and Bitbucket
# Authenticate JIRA with Bitbucket on the Activity Stream:
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64124].
  {panel}

Since JIRA is a source-available project, but not open-source, I don't think it makes sense to use bountysource.com or something similar.

In this day and age, every company has finite internal resources... why not make use of external resources as much as possible?  JIRA core developers I'm sure have their commercial and business-minded priorities, which may not exactly line up with customer-demand for specific features.

As a business, we need to keep moving.  We need to keep innovating and focus on our own core products.  We're not a JIRA company, we're a JIRA user, and we don't have the time to dig into JIRA source code and tackle making a significant change.

Let's offer development services to the community, at fair market value to address badly needed JIRA features, and JIRA Service Desk features, and any other projects that Atlassian Offers where customers can download the source code.

We would gladly pay $200, $500, $1000+, for a specific badly needed feature to be developed by the community that was vetted and incorporated into Atlassian mainline products and will be backed by their amazing support and development staff.  I'm sure this could be turned into a crowd funded development as well.  Or even a cloud based team development approach.  Maybe an entire new product line for Atlassian?  Imagine Atlassian CrowdFund... buy the platform and poof, now you have your own a crowd funding site.  But I digress.

Looking at the vote counts for many of these unaddressed open issues (mainly feature requests) in the tracker, with vote counts in the 100's or more or even 1000's or more, make me believe that it's definitely possible that 50 people watching an issue, who desperately need this new feature, would contribute $100 or more to see this issue completed, a $5000 or more community development bounty would surely attract some interest.
fields.summary: Create a bounty-based marketplace for Jira Bugs/Features

h3. Summary
When rich text editor is enabled, custom field would not work properly
h3. Environment
* JIRA 7.2.4

# Create a custom field. (In my test I am using multi text field)

# Create and issue
# Try to edit the created issue and for the custom field while in *visual mode* select some wiki style markup function.

h3. Expected Results
You will be able to switch the editor between text and visual for the custom field

h3. Actual Results

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64114].
  {panel}

Reporting a bug against JIRA involves too many steps, including some unclear and some tedious, such that it’s almost not worth doing.

Expected results:
# You can create a bug report for JIRA in the same way you can create a bug report for SourceTree.

Actual:
# Attempt to create a bug against the JIRA project. Upon changing the type of report to “bug”, several fields disappear, including the Description field, and an infoblast appears with the text
{quote}Help us fix bugs faster 

To help us get the right details and fix bugs as quickly as possible, submit your bug report in our support system. 

You can still view, watch, comment on, and vote for existing bugs by searching for them in this project.{quote}
It has two buttons: “Report a new bug” and “Search for an existing bug”. Nobody has reported this issue yet, so click “Report a new bug”.
# Find yourself directed to Support System Hell. Find on page for “bug”—no results.
# Maybe creating an account will make the bug reporter appear? Create an account. No dice.
# Back on the Support System Hell Homepage, scan the items again:
#* JIRA Core documentation: not a place to report bugs, and also is JIRA Core different from just plain JIRA?
#* Knowledge base: not a place to report bugs
#* Community: not a place to report bugs, and probably part of the corporate Web disease that is the one-eyed answering the questions of the blind
#* Billing & licensing help: probably not helpful when it comes to reporting bugs
#* Product feedback: maybe…? No, wait, it just takes you back to the beginning of this mess.
#* Contact Technical Support: you don’t need additional people in the loop, especially ones who will, at worst, walk through the Uselessly Simplistic Official Support Flowchart to no avail, and at best, will report your issue without “helpfully” summarizing it and thereby losing potentially important information.
# The best possible outcome from the Support System Hell Homepage seems to be that the bug gets reported by tech support without modification, which means that you’ve gained nothing and wasted the time of a tech support employee.
# Grumble under your breath at the time lost creating a support account (which you’ll never use) and trying to navigate Support System Hell. Go back to the JIRA issue tracker, report the bug as a “suggestion”.
fields.summary: The JIRA bug reporting process has too many roadblocks

h3. Summary
When importing users that currently belong to an external directory in JIRA to the internal user directory, their passwords will not be copied over if a different encryption is being used on both directories (SHA and PKCS for example).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect JIRA to an external user directory that uses SHA as its password encryption.
# Use the built in user migration tool to migrate users from the external directory into the internal directory.

h3. Expected Results
Users are copied with their current password.

h3. Actual Results
The users' passwords will not be copied over properly - a PKCS string will be generated, but they will not be able to log in with the original password.
 
h3.Workaround
Resetting the affected users' password seems to be the only way to work around this.

h3. Summary
When renaming an issue type that is used in existing issues does not change in edit, create, and edit issue type from view issue.

# Create issue type.
# Create issue with new issue type.
# Rename new issue type.
# Check edit, create, and edit issue type from view issue screen,

h3. Expected Results
The new name will be displayed.
h3. Actual Results
The old issue type is still displayed.

h3.Workaround

*Option 1*
Go to Jira settings > Issues > Issue Type schemes > Edit the desired scheme > drag and drop affected Issue type somewhere up or down on the list and then save the configuration. The Issue type can now be moved to the original position if required.

*Option 2*
Restarting JIRA resolves this. Please see [Start and Stop JIRA applications|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver071/start-and-stop-jira-applications-855475782.html] for reference.

fields.description:
h4. +Summary+

If Confluence uses a context path in its URL, JIRA is unable to find a page using its tiny link when linking a JIRA issue to a Confluence page.
h4. +Steps to reproduce+
 # Configure JIRA to run on [http://localhost:8730/jira]
 # Configure Confluence to run on [http://localhost:6001/cfl]
 # Link them together using applinks
 # Open a Confluence page and get its tiny link
 # Open a JIRA issue -> More -> Link -> Confluence Page -> paste the tiny link -> Link

h4. +Expected behavior+

The link is added successfully.
h4. +Actual behavior+

JIRA cannot find the link and throws a 404 error in the log:
 !tiny.png|thumbnail!
{code:java}
2017-02-14 23:13:40,939 http-nio-8730-exec-2 ERROR admin 1393x1101x1 ki7q6c 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 /secure/LinkConfluencePage.jspa [c.a.j.p.link.confluence.LinkConfluencePage] Invalid response from getting the pageId: 404: Not Found
{code}
h4. +Notes / Workarounds+
 * By default, Confluence will resolve the tiny link to a relative URL when used with HTTP/1.1, which fails when a context path is used for Confluence.
 * The standard (non-tiny) link of the same Confluence page can be linked successfully
 * If Confluence has no context path e.g. [http://localhost:6001|http://localhost:6001/], tiny links can be linked successfully
 * If using a context path, two _possible_ workarounds would be to either:
 ** append the system property *org.apache.catalina.STRICT_SERVLET_COMPLIANCE=true* to Confluence's {{catalina.properties}} file and restart Confluence, or
** modify the *context* element in Confluence's context.xml file to disallow relative redirects, e.g.:
{{<Context useRelativeRedirects="false">}}
and restart Confluence.

Be sure to thoroughly test either of the above two workarounds in a test environment before implementing in production to ensure no functionality is impacted.
fields.summary: Can't link JIRA issue to Confluence page by using tiny URL when Confluence uses a Context Path

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64097].
  {panel}

The system should be designed with much heavier use of cache on all levels.

Some examples of poor design in Jira that your dev team should attend to:
 * Trying to edit a comment, there's no reason for an Ajax request to load the dialog. The text is in the page and so are the edit tools. Only ajax request should be on updating it.
 * Trying to change assignee on an issue would load the users list via Ajax request. Why not cache this in localstorage?

There are many more occasions where needless requests are made and the system thus responds much slower than needed. Perhaps it becomes more evident on the cloud _service_ which is obviously overloaded. I could now see that refresh a simple issue page would take 1.1-2.5 seconds to fetch the HTML part of the page (without resources). This should have constantly been under 1sec and the changes clarify the server is overloaded.
fields.summary: Improve Cloud platform performance

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}


h3. Summary
Sometimes, the sidebar does not load properly while browsing an issue. No icon appears on the sidebar and message "Unable to render element due to an error" appears on the top of the sidebar. Users have to refresh few times to get the sidebar loaded properly.

*Fix notes*: BigPipe is our latest invention separating request from actual rendering. For example - it allows us to render issues faster and then sidebar at the end. However as this technology is used outside of server Jira too it contains timeout feature. Timeout is calculated from the beginning of the request, so when the whole request is too long, the pipe will give up on rendering. Fix removes this timeout for Jira.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
N/A as this happens intermittently for some customers

h3. Expected Results
The issue details and sidebar are displayed without any error

h3. Actual Results
Occasionally the sidebar shows "Unable to render element due to an error" while the below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-jira.log}} file:
{noformat}
2017-02-14 15:57:28,689 http-nio-8080-exec-202 ERROR anonymous 6x15350x1 oclbhd 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 /browse/DESK-4095 [c.a.p.webresource.assembler.DefaultWebResourceAssembler] Error generating bigpipe content for 'sidebar-id': Deadline exceeded
java.lang.RuntimeException: Deadline exceeded
	at com.atlassian.plugin.webresource.bigpipe.QueueFutureCompletionService.forceCompleteAll(QueueFutureCompletionService.java:62)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.webresource.bigpipe.BigPipe.forceCompleteAll(BigPipe.java:33)
...
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Disable _BigPipe_. That will revert to pre 7.2 page rendering behaviour:
* View Issue is going to take longer to load as big-piped panels (e.g.: Comments section, Projects Sidebar) will be rendered eagerly rather than postponed.

Steps: 
# Navigate to {{http:<JIRA-base-URL>/secure/admin/SiteDarkFeatures!Default.jspa}} to get to the Dark Features page.
# Enable the dark feature *com.atlassian.jira.config.BIG_PIPE_KILLSWITCH*
fields.summary: Sidebar fails to display with 'Unable to render element due to an error' message when viewing issue due to BigPipe timeouts

We'd like to authorize a group of users to have permission to only create new projects, but NOT to be able to alter or add workflows, custom fields, screens, etc.

Currently, when you authorize a user to be able to create new projects, he/she is also able to change the aforementioned 'object types' in JIRA, which are standardized and should not be altered or added to.

To my knowledge, JIRA does not allow to differentiate between these kind of authorisations.

Adding additional Global Permissions or adding more levels of user permissions would help keep the system manageable for those responsible for maintaining it at company/organisation level.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

*Summary:*  Worklog data is not stored according to the user profile time zone but specific to the server timezone (UTC). 

*Problem Definition:*
This can create confusing results when users from different time zones are entering time. It is hard to gauge without some manual conversion what time they actually. In some cases it can throw the figure off by day i.e. 10/31/2017 5 PM PST Converts to 11/01/2017 2:00 AM CET.

*Suggested Solution:*
Have an additional field where worklog entries are stored according to the user profile timezone. See comments by Mark on [JRA-35503|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-35503?focusedCommentId=532102&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-532102]. 

*Why this is important:* 
Right now there is unnecessary friction and leg work for the users end to correct this problem.
fields.summary: Store worklog data according to user profile timezone in a different field.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64089].
  {panel}

*Summary:* Our documentation does not clear state in either the [User Profile| or [Logging work|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira064/logging-work-on-an-issue-720416377.html] or [User Profile Timezone|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACORESERVER072/Managing+your+user+profile]  that the worklog data is not stored according to the user profile time zone but specific to the server timezone (UTC). 

*Problem Definition:*
This can create confusing results when users from different time zones are entering time. It is hard to gauge without some manual conversion what time they actually. In some cases it can throw the figure off by day i.e. 10/31/2017 5 PM PST Converts to 11/01/2017 2:00 AM CET.

*Suggested Solution:*
Update documentation to reflect how work log data is actually stored. 

*Why this is important:* 
This creates a lot of confusion when tracking time within JIRA. JIRA treats it as the long entry as an absolute point that is stored in UTC as reflected by the developers comment on [JRA-35503|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-35503?focusedCommentId=532112&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-532112]
fields.summary: Update documentation that work log entries are stored in UTC Server System Time.

fields.description:
h1. Problem

The problem is related to the wiki fields (both system wiki-style fields and custom fields with "Wiki Style Renderer" renderer) being hidden on the issue create screen for a particular issue type.

A JavaScript error is thrown in web browsers when changing the project issue type via Issue Create screen:
{code:java}
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'triggerEvent' of undefined
    at Object.detached (batch.js?agile_global_admin_condition=true&healthcheck-resources=true&is-server-instance=true&is-sy…:68051)
{code}
or
{code:java}
Exception: Uncaught TypeError: j.trigger is not a function
{code}
h1. Steps to reproduce the problem
# Kanban Board > Create Issue
# Select *Configure Fields*
# Set to Custom
# Uncheck a Field that has a *Wiki Style Render* enabled (i.e. Description)
# Change issue type > ERROR

h1. Workaround

The easiest workaround is to show all the [wiki-style fields|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer073/Configuring+renderers#Configuringrenderers-Renderablefields] for issue create screen of a particular issue type:
 * You could simply show all fields in there:  !show all fields.png|width=800,height=176!

 * Or just check to show only the particular [wiki-style fields|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer073/Configuring+renderers#Configuringrenderers-Renderablefields] (e.g. on the following screenshots "Environment" system field and "MyCustomField1" use Wiki Style Renderer):
 ## !cf.png|width=255,height=164!
 ## !env.png|width=255,height=164!
 ## !all.png|width=255,height=164!

 

_BTW Disabling the RTE plugin won't help since the issue is in good old JIRA Wiki Editor plugin, not in RTE._
fields.summary: JavaScript error upon setting issue type in create screen when there are hidden fields using the wiki renderer

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Trigger JIRA Configuration Tool
 # Got to "Web Server" tab
 # Setup "Profile"  to use HTTPS
 # Save changes.
 # Start JIRA.

h3. Expected Results

JIRA starts with SSL enabled
h3. Actual Results

Tomcat fails and is unable to start. The below exception is thrown in the catalina.out file:
{noformat}
06-Jan-2017 11:46:26.846 SEVERE [main] org.apache.catalina.connector.Connector.<init> Protocol handler instantiation failed
 java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Protocol
	at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:381)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:424)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:357)
	at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:264)
	at org.apache.catalina.connector.Connector.<init>(Connector.java:74)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.ConnectorCreateRule.begin(ConnectorCreateRule.java:64)
	at org.apache.tomcat.util.digester.Digester.startElement(Digester.java:1190)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.startElement(AbstractSAXParser.java:509)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractXMLDocumentParser.emptyElement(AbstractXMLDocumentParser.java:182)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanStartElement(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:1339)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl$FragmentContentDriver.next(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:2784)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentScannerImpl.next(XMLDocumentScannerImpl.java:602)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanDocument(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:505)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(XML11Configuration.java:841)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(XML11Configuration.java:770)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XMLParser.parse(XMLParser.java:141)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.parse(AbstractSAXParser.java:1213)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.jaxp.SAXParserImpl$JAXPSAXParser.parse(SAXParserImpl.java:643)
	at org.apache.tomcat.util.digester.Digester.parse(Digester.java:1458)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Catalina.load(Catalina.java:578)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Catalina.load(Catalina.java:629)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap.load(Bootstrap.java:311)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap.main(Bootstrap.java:494) {noformat}
h3. Workaround

Modify JIRA_INSTALL/conf/server.xml. Change the protocol on your HTTPS connector to: {{protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol"}}
 * If you do not use the HTTP Connector but use the AJP Connector instead, use the AJP NIO protocol instead.
 ** The AJP connector is: {{protocol="org.apache.coyote.ajp.AjpNioProtocol"}}

*Refer to [Upgrade notes for 7.3|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRASOFTWARE/JIRA+Software+7.3.x+upgrade+notes] for instructions. See Running JIRA applications over SSL.*

See [Running JIRA applications over SSL or HTTPS |https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer073/Running+JIRA+applications+over+SSL+or+HTTPS]for full directions on running JIRA over SSL or HTTPS.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64074].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Unlicensed users are not able to receive notifications for JIRA Software and JIRA Core. As other customers report, this used to work in the past. But while taking multiple tests into Cloud Instances (this was only tested with Cloud).

To test that you can:
# Create a user without any application access
# Create a notification scheme that includes this user (we tested by allowing browse projects permission and notification through a user custom field and also through watchers field)
# Add user to that issue as a watcher or using a custom field
# Make sure the user has browse permission access to that issue
# Try to generate notification
# No Notification is sent, neither information is thrown on outgoing mail log

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow this type of user to receive notifications.


h3. Why this is important
There are use cases when users need to receive only mail notifications and will not need to use JIRA internal functionalities, this is demanding this kind of users to consume a license only to receive e-mails.
 
h3. Workaround 
Send the notification to a single email address, without creating the user with no application access. 
This should work since JRA-63395 has been fixed.
fields.summary: Unlicensed users do not receive issue notifications

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JIRA Service Desk tickets sometimes do not transition correctly when transitioning through default automation rules.

The issue will change status correctly, but will not actually transition causing the issue to become stuck as the status has moved on. 

For example,  the issue status has changed to Waiting for Support (WFS) but the transition never completed successfully and is still reported as Waiting for Customer (WFC) in the issue history - when these should both be Waiting for support (WFS)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a brand new JIRA SD 3.3.0 instance
# Create a new Service Desk - using the IT template
# Create an agent and customer
# Create an issue as the customer through the portal
# Transition back and forth using comments only until the issue falls into the incorrect status


h3. Expected Results
The ticket will transition correctly after a comment is added.

h3. Actual Results
The status will appear to be correct, but the transition button will still appear on the ticket.
 
h3. Notes
This warning may appear in the logs: 
{code:borderStyle=solid}
/secure/AjaxIssueAction!default.jspa [c.a.s.i.f.customer.request.CustomerRequestInternalManagerImpl] The first customer request status found, does not appear to match the actual issues current customer request status. Attempt a re-sort operation before return results   
{code}

h3.Workarounds
# Run the workflow check - check workflow current step entries in the [integrity checker|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver072/using-the-database-integrity-checker-828788073.html], this will show that there are issues which require fixing:
{{The current step associated with the workflow entry with id xxxxx has an incorrect stepId.}}
# Use the Fix button and JIRA will fix the issues directly in the database. 

Alternatively, transition each misaligned issue using the transition button on the Agent view so that automation will work again.
fields.summary: Transitioning a Service Desk issue using default automation rules intermittently fails due to a race conditon
Be able to sort Custom Fields by Type

h3. Summary

JIRA's Permission Helper might throw misleading results when the user that is being tested is not on any groups defined to be able to access JIRA.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Ensure the {{Create Issue}} permission for this project is set as {{Any logged in user}}
# Create a user with no Application Access
# Use the permission helper to verify if the user does have {{Create Issue}} permission on the newly created project

h3. Expected Results

The permission helper should notify that the user does not have application access, thus cannot create an issue on a JIRA Software Project

h3. Actual Results

The permission helper returns that the user is able to create issues in the target project.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When converting an issue, from an issue type that does not require components and has no components, to an issue type that does require components, 
it does not allow you to set the components if the parent issue has sub-tasks.

This only occurs when the issues are not being moved within the *same* project -- when you change the issue type via bulk move.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two field configurations (one with the field "Component/s" as required and another one with the field set as optional)
# Change the field configuration from Story issue type to set the field "Component/s" as required (make sure the parent issue has at least one sub-task)
# Change the field configuration from Bug issue type to set field "Component/s" as optional (make sure the parent issue has at least one sub-task)
# Try to convert the issue from Bug to Story
# The field "Component/s" has a greyed out field value not allowing to change it (screenshot attached)

h3. Expected Results
JIRA should allow to update the field "Component/s"

h3. Actual Results
If we have sub-tasks in the parent issue, the field "Component/s" will not allow you to change it
If the parent issue doesn't have any sub-tasks, it will let you update the "Component/s" field

h3. Workaround
Move the issue to another project first, then back to the target project and issue type.
fields.summary: Convert issue type with sub-tasks not working

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The lack of SNI support in JIRA for remote events prevents workflow triggers from being created. The other features of Application Links, such as the Development Panel, work without issue. 

JIRA bundles and older version of the {{atlassian-remote-event}} library which includes a version of {{httpclient}} that does not have SNI support. Version 2.0.2 of remote events includes SNI support and an updated version of {{httpclient}}. 

h3. Environment
* Reverse proxy serving multiple SSL certs

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup JIRA and Bitbucket Server behind a reverse proxy that serves multiple SSL certificates
# Connect JIRA to Bitbucket Server via AppLinks
# Attempt to setup a workflow trigger, for example, to transition an issue when a pull request is created

h3. Expected Results
Trigger is created successfully

h3. Actual Results

Diagnostics for the trigger fail and JIRA reports that it is not able to communicate to Bitbucket Server.

* Enabling package to have debug on *com.atlassian.event.remote.impl.diagnostics* in order to see below logging

The below exception is thrown in the jira.log file:
{noformat}
2017-01-28 07:48:24,710 ajp-nio-8009-exec-10 DEBUG luis.guevara 468x445x1 ktche5 73.209.192.223 /rest/dev-status/1.0/trigger/diagnostics/pullrequests [c.a.e.r.impl.diagnostics.DefaultRemoteEventConsumerStatus] Unexpected exception querying 06aededb-4f45-3c9b-b094-69b8a3e69c21 at https://bitbucket.company.com/rest/remote-event-producer/1/capabilities
javax.net.ssl.SSLException: hostname in certificate didn't match: <bitbucket.company.com> != <some.other.server.company.com>
{noformat}
You may alternatively see the following exception:
{noformat}javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: sun.security.validator.ValidatorException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target{noformat}

h3.Workaround

Bypass the reverse proxy and follow [How to create an unproxied application link|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/how-to-create-an-unproxied-application-link-719095740.html].
fields.summary: Workflow triggers not working when behind a reverse proxy that serves multiple SSL certificates

fields.description:
h2. Summary
After upgrading JIRA from 6.2.7 to 7.2.2 the workflows in the workflow editor  are display in a different way to how it was originally displayed in 6.2.7.
Please note that exporting and re-importing the affected workflow does not make any difference, the workflows are still displayed in an unreadable way. 

h2. Environment
* It was reproduced in a JIRA vanilla environment.


h2. Steps to Reproduce
# Install JIRA 6.2.7
# Create a Project to have active and inactive workflows
# Create additional workflows if needed (Please note this is an optional step as the problem can be reproduced with vanilla workflows)
# Check how workflows are displayed
# Perform an upgrade to 7.2.2
# Check how workflows are displayed


h2. Expected Results
The workflows should be displayed in the same way they were originally displayed in 6.2.7 .

h2. Actual Results
The workflows are displayed in an totally different way compared to how they were displayed before the upgrade.  The more complex the workflows are the more difficult to understand them is, as some statuses will overlap with other statuses and transitions.

h2. Workaround
The only workaround is to manually organize each affected workflow.

*It is also important to note that following the upgrade path 6.2 >> 6.3 (latest release) >> 6.4 (latest release) >> 7.0 (latest release) >>7.2.2 (latest release) this issue can be avoided as workflows are displayed as they were originally organized when they were created*
fields.summary: After upgrading from 6.2.7 to 7.2.2 workflows are displayed in a different way than how they were originally displayed
